summary: Some major central banks have become more accommodative, while geopolitical disruption continues to cast a shadow over growth. All told, we forecast global economic growth of about 3% for 2020. Regionally, we expect the lowest growth from Japan, the UK, and the eurozone and the highest from Asian emerging markets and China.

summary: The year 2020 saw the global economy plunged into economic turmoil. The shape of economic growth in the coming year is dependent on a wide variety of factors. East Asia – in particular, China, Japan and South Korea – has managed the virus well. Much of the developed world and many emerging markets have struggled to contain the pandemic.

summary: 2023 Investment Outlook APAC Version 1 Executive summary Introduction In September, the World Bank warned that “central banks around the world have been raising interest rates this year with a degree of synchronicity not seen over the past five decades” We believe we are currently in the contraction phase of the economic cycle with global growth below trend and decelerating. We think the contraction globally will be a modest soft patch, although some economies will be hit harder than others. If inflation remains stubbornly high, we assume central banks will continue tightening monetary policy for longer.

summary: Many of the world’s central banks, having largely succeeded in curbing inflation, are now easing monetary policies with the aim of stimulating growth. In 2025, we anticipate signs of economic deceleration to be counteracted by the supportive impact of the global rate-cutting cycle. Overall, we expect a conducive environment for risk assets, particularly in non- US developed markets, small capitalization stocks, and value sectors in the US.

summary: Government and central bank support appears to have carried economies through the worst of the Covid-19 crisis. After a decade of US market dominance, it could be Asia’s turn to shine.

summary: Two years ago, the U.S. and global economies were rocked by two enormous shocks. Pandemic and the policy response triggered giant waves in economic output, employment and inflation. For investors, the key to investing in 2022 and beyond is to navigate what is left of these waves.

summary: Developed world growth to slow with housing activity bearing the brunt. Housing markets are, as usual, the first to react to central banks touching the monetary brake. Construction will weaken, spending on furniture and other household durables will fall and falling house prices could weigh on consumer spending.

summary: As we head into 2024, a combination of solid activity and falling inflation has seen the market narrative increasingly shift towards the prospects of a soft landing. We think it's too early for the central banks to declare outright victory over inflation, and anticipate that rate cuts in 2024 are unlikely to pre-empt economic weakness. Investors should focus on locking in yields currently on offer in the bond market.

summary: Our central expectation is that President Trump’s policy agenda will be growth supportive. But there are risks, particularly if the balance of fiscal stimulus, tariffs and immigration curbs prompt more inflation than real growth. For equity market leadership, how the technology boom evolves is more important than who is in the White House.

summary: UBS unveils Year Ahead outlook for 2021: A year of renewal. We see economic output and corporate earnings rebounding to pre-pandemic levels in 2021. Investors should consider broadening their portfolios beyond large US companies. Investors looking for "The Next Big Thing" should seek opportunities in fintech, greentech, healthtech, or 5G.

summary: UBS Global Wealth Management’s Chief Investment Office Year Ahead 2022 outlook. 2022 is expected to be a year of two halves, with high rates of economic growth and inflation in the first half. Investors should seek opportunities in the net-zero carbon transition and the “ABC” of disruptive technologies – artificial intelligence, big data, and cybersecurity.

summary: UBS’s Chief Investment Office looks ahead to a year of inflections, which will shape the investment landscape in the year to come. High inflation, rising rates, and slowing growth expectations favor a relatively defensive stance on risky assets. Defensive sectors should prove relatively insulated from a weakening economy.

summary: UBS’s Chief Investment Office sees us entering “a new world” in 2024. Investors should focus on quality, get in balance, and stay disciplined yet agile. There are opportunities to capture growth in leaders from disruption, including generative AI.

summary: We enter 2020 with the conviction that at this stage a slowdown is in the nature of the cycle, but there are some specific features that characterise it as a peculiar regime. The retreat in global trade is causing a major change in the structure of growth, but does not point to a full-blown recession. Monetary and fiscal policy combination, a prominent theme going forward, may extend the current cycle further.

summary: The Covid-19 pandemic drove an unprecedented collapse in economic activity in H1, which was followed by a desynchronised rebound. The recovery phase has been uneven, with the virus cycle dictating the sequence of it. We believe that the damage to the global economy will last well beyond 2021.

summary: The world is preparing to face its greatest ever challenges: the energy transition to fight the inexorable climate crisis and the development of an inclusive growth model. Huge fiscal stimulus, along with private capital, is crucial for the ambitious investment needed to reach Net Zero emission targets by 2050.

summary: Turning tides in growth, inflation and monetary policy will generate opportunities for investors to rotate from a more defensive to a more constructive stance during the year. Assuming that the Middle East crisis remains contained, we expect a weaker global economic outlook, mainly driven by the slowdown in Developed Markets. The US will tiptoe into a recession in H1, as tight ﬁnancial conditions begin to bite on consumption and business sentiment. In Japan, growth should moderate but stay above potential.

summary: An increasingly unpredictable policy environment is undermining economic activity globally. Inflation is likely to remain soft in 2020. Slowing global growth and elevated uncertainty create a fragile backdrop for markets. The risk of a large drawdown for equities and other high-beta assets remains elevated.

summary: In China, we see the robust recovery extending in 2021 with growth of 9%. Elsewhere, we expect growth of 5% in the U.S. and 5%, and 6% in emerging markets. Given a lower-for-longer rate outlook, we find it hard to see a material uptick in fixed income returns.

summary: Vanguard research December 2021 Vanguard economic and market outlook for 2022: Striking a better balance. Inflation has remained high across most economies, driven both by higher demand and lower supply.

summary: We expect monetary policy to become increasingly restrictive in real terms. Higher interest rates mean higher returns for long-term bond investors. We see global bonds as close to fair value. Meanwhile, the return premium of global equities over global bonds we expect over the next decade has further reduced.

summary: This year, we have modified our process to incorporate climate change, a subsegment of environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors, into our return forecasts. Climate change’s effect on these variables flows directly into GDP growth and inflation. Our analysis points to a decade of subdued returns for most major asset classes.

summary: Long-term return expectations for capital markets serve as key inputs into our strategic asset allocation process for multi-asset portfolios. The next decade will likely be characterized by returns below historical averages across all major asset classes. Given higher valuations and lower risk premiums in equity markets, our analysis paints a picture of relatively low expected returns for equities.

summary: Long-term return expectations for capital markets serve as key inputs into our strategic asset allocation process for multi-asset portfolios. For the 10-year period (2025–2034), higher valuations and lower risk premiums point to below-average expected returns for equities. However, we expect returns for both stocks and bonds will generally outpace inflation.

summary: The bond market inked its second year in a row of negative returns, a feat not seen since 1958-59. High inflation and the end of pandemic-related transfer payments reduced real disposable income in 2022. 2023 may actually see this situation reverse as the drivers of inflation give way and the pace of inflation drops.

summary: The centerpiece of our 2025 global economic outlook is a U.S. growth acceleration that leads the world economy. Equity markets seem to have embraced the soft-landing scenario since mid-2023. We favor shifting those holdings into broadening equity-market opportunities.

summary: This article updates our estimates average of nearly 5% (since 19001) of medium-term (5- to 10-year) returns. The article also includes two focus topics: one highlighting the case slightly higher for equities, and for emerging market equities. And the other assessing the impact of large interest rate rises on various risk premia.

summary: In 2023, expected returns fell for private credit, equities but increased further for the boom asset class of 2023. We conclude with a slimmer equity risk premia. Principal expected real return of a global and Global Co-Head of the Portfolio 60/40 portfolio held steady at 3%.

summary: In 2024, equity markets rallied for a second consecutive year but our expected returns – based on current valuations – continue to imply risk premia are compressed. The expected real return of a global 60/40 portfolio has risen to 3.5%, driven by average of nearly 5% since 1900.

summary: The recent virus outbreak leads us to reconsider our initial view that global growth would edge higher in 2020. We see interest rate-sensitive sectors such as housing firming, but the broader growth pickup may be delayed. The increase of uncertainty reemphasizes the need of sources of resilience. A focus on sustainability can also help add resilience to portfolios.

summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated profound shifts in how economies and societies operate. We see transformations across sustainability, inequality, geopolitics and macro policy. The new investment order is still evolving, and investors will need to adapt. The traditional business cycle playbook does not apply to the pandemic.

summary: The Great Moderation, the four-decade period of largely stable activity and inflation, is behind us. The new regime of greater macro and market volatility is playing out. A recession is foretold; central banks are on course to overtighten policy as they seek to tame inflation. This new regime calls for rethinking bonds, our second theme.

summary: The new regime of greater macro and market volatility has resulted in greater uncertainty and dispersion of returns. This is a sea change from relying on the one-and-done asset allocations that worked so well during the Great Moderation. We believe this is a time to grab the investing wheel – and seize the opportunities the new regime has on offer.

summary: We remain bullish on Equity markets for the coming year despite a likely uptick in volatility under the Trump administration.
